Description: Neutrophils are the most abundant leukocytes in blood. They and are essential in fighting infections and aid in wound healing. In recent years, there has been a growing appreciation for the diverse functions of neutrophils in cancer. Experimental data from mouse models have shown that neutrophils can both negatively and positively affect tumor progression: On one hand, neutrophils can be potent killers of cancer cells, but on the other hand, they can also have immune suppressive, pro-angiogenic, and pro-metastatic functions.   This educational session will include presentations that discuss how neutrophils alter the tumor microenvironment and the mechanisms by which they regulate metastasis and responses to therapy, including immunotherapy. A better understanding of the roles of neutrophils in cancer is likely to provide opportunities for using them as clinical biomarkers, for therapeutic targeting of their anti-metastatic effects, and for harnessing of their immunomodulatory functions.
SearchResultBody: ED036. Understanding Neutrophil Dynamics in Cancer: Mouse to Human and Back Again
Title: Understanding Neutrophil Dynamics in Cancer: Mouse to Human and Back Again
